facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 239 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal -No. 239 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from Patna High Court judgment and decree dated December 12, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1950, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 188 of 1945

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated December 18, 1945, of Additional Subordinate Judge, IV Class, Gaya, in Title Suit No. 4 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 18, 1945, of the Court of the Additional Subordinate Judge, IV Class, Gaya, in Title Suit No. 4 of 1945.

facts.text: Deokinand, common ancestor of plaintiff-respondents 1 to 4 and proforma respondents 6 to 12, executed document dated August 20, 1923.

anchor.surface_text: Deokinand, the companymon ancestor of plaintiff-respondents 1 to 4 and proforma respondents 6 to 12, executed a document dated August 20, 1923,

facts.text: Document hypothecated eight annas milkiat share in mauza Lodipur, Mahimabigha, Tauze No. 4246 to Mahant Tokhnarain Puri, predecessor-in-interest of defendant 1.

anchor.surface_text: in favour of Mahant Tokhnarain Puri of Nadra, the predecessor-ininterest of defendant 1, hypothecating eight annas milkiat share in mauza Lodipur, Mahimabigha, Tauze No. 4246

facts.text: Purpose of document was to discharge debt of Rs. 31,701 payable by Deokinand to the Mahanth.

anchor.surface_text: for the purpose of discharging a debt of Rs. 31,701 payable by him to the Mahanth.

facts.text: Respondents claim the document is a usufructuary mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: There are companyflicting versions in regard to the nature of this transaction-respondents claim it to be a usufructuary mortgage,

facts.text: Appellant asserts the document is a lease.

anchor.surface_text: while the appellant asserts it to be a lease

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondents instituted Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 for redemption, rendition of accounts and recovery of surplus profits.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondents instituted Title Suit No. 4 of 1945 in the Court of the Additional Subordinate Judge 1V, Gaya, for redemption of the said document on the basis that it was a usufructuary mortgage, for rendition of accounts and for the recovery of surplus profits due to them.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded the document was a lease, not mortgage; if mortgage, anomalous with no statutory accounts; or s.77 TPA applies.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded, inter alia, that the suit for redemption was number maintainable as the document was number a mortgage but lease, that on the assumption that it was a mortgage it would only be an anomalous mortgage in respect where of there was numberstatutory liability to render accounts to the plaintiff, that even if it was a usufructuary mortgage, it was governed by the provisions of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held document created usufructuary mortgage not lease, s.77 TPA applies, no liability to render accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge held that the document created a usufructuary mortgage and number a lease and that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applied to the document exonerating the appellant from any liability to render accounts.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge gave conditional decree for possession on depositing Rs. 26,839-7-0 within six months.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the learned Subordinate Judge gave a companyditional decree in favour of respondents I to 4 for possession on their depositing in Court a sum of Rs. 26,839-7-0 within six months from the date of the decree.

facts.text: High Court agreed document was usufructuary mortgage but differed on s.77 applicability.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the learned Subordinate Judge that the document was a sufructuary mortgage but differed from him on the question of applicability of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: High Court set aside Subordinate Judge decree and passed preliminary decree for redemption, sale on default, and rendition of accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the decree of the learned Subordinate Judge and passed instead a preliminary decree for redemption and sale on default of payment the decree also directed the rendition of accounts between the parties in the light of the directions given in the judgment.

facts.text: Second defendant preferred appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant against whom the decree was passed preferred the above appeal.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate tinder Art. 133  1   a  of the Constitution of India is directed against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature at Patna

facts.text: Pre-existing thika lease dated April 21, 1922, in favour of Munshi Dodraj Lal alias Munshi Jatadhari Lal for 9 years, Rs. 2,205 peshgi, rent Rs. 2,205.

anchor.surface_text: It was also stated in the document that in respect of the said property there was a pre-existing thika  lease  dated April 21, 1922, in favour of Munshi Dodraj Lal alias Munshi Jatadhari Lal, for a period of 9 years and that under the said lease, Rs. 2,205 was taken by the executant as peshgi money without interest and the rent was fixed at a sum of Rs. 2,205.

facts.text: Document term 15 years from 1331 Fasli to 1345 Fasli.

anchor.surface_text: for a term of 15 years, companymencing from 1331 Fasli to 1345 Fasli

facts.text: Peshgi Rs. 31,701: Rs. 29,496 at 1/2% per month interest, Rs. 2,205 without interest.

anchor.surface_text: for a peshgi money of Rs. 31,701that Rs. 29,496, the peshgi money bearing interest at 1/2 per cent. per month and Rs. 2,205, tile peshgi money without interest,

facts.text: During thikadari, ijaradar to realize rent Rs. 2,205, set off Rs. 1,769-12-0 interest, pay Rs. 435-4-0 to executant.

anchor.surface_text: he should realize the rent from the above-named thikadars and their heirs and representatives in accordance with the stipulations made in the thika patta and kabuliat as representative of me, the executant, and bring it into his possession and use, that is to say, on his own authority he should set off Rs. 1,769-12-0 on account of the interest on the peshgi money bearing interest mentioned in this deed, year after year, and pay the remaining sum of Rs. 435-4-0

facts.text: Thikadari interest expired in 1338 Fasli.

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the thikadari interest in 1338 Fasli,

facts.text: Supreme Court held the document is a mortgage, not a lease.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, numberscope for the argument in this case that the document is a lease and number a mortgage. We hold, agreeing with the High Court, that the document is a mortgage and number a lease.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.77 TPA applies, mortgagee not liable to render accounts.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies to the document and therefore the mortgagee is number liable to render any account to the mortgagor.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court decree and restored Subordinate Judge decree.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the decree of the High Court is set aside and that of the Subordinate Judge is restored.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 23, 1958 by SUBBA RAO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. May 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-
This appeal by certificate tinder Art. 133  1   a  of the Constitution of India is directed against the judgment

issues.text: The point to be first decided is whether the transaction is a lease as contended by the contesting respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant against whom the decree was passed preferred the above appeal. The point to be first decided is whether the transaction is a lease as contended by the contesting respondents. The only guiding rule that can be extracted from the cases on the subject is that the intention of the parties must be looked into and that once you get a debt with security of land for its redemption, then the arrangement is a mortgage by whatever name it is called

issues.text: whether the document did not create a usufructuary mortgage but only an anomalous mortgage

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it was contended by the learned Counsel for the appellant that the document did not create an usufructuary mortgage but only an anomalous mortgage. This contention was raised as a foundation to the argument that if the document was an anomalous mortgage, the rights and liabilities of the parties would be governed by the terms of the contract between them and not by the provisions of s. 76 of the Transfer of Property Act.

issues.text: If it was a usufructuary mortgage, [is the appellant] not liable to render accounts to the mortgagor, as, under the mortgage deed, he was authorized to take the receipts in lieu of interest within the meaning of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: We shall, therefore, proceed to consider the question on the alternative basis. If it was a usufructuary mortgage, it is contended by the appellant that he was not liable to render accounts to the mortgagor, as, under the mortgage deed, he was authorized to take the receipts in lieu of interest within the meaning of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act. The relevant provisions of the Transfer of Property Act are as follows Section 76 When during the continuance of the mortgage, the mortgagee takes possession of the mortgaged property,-

issues.text: the question whether this section [s.98] excludes the operation of other relevant provisions of the Act, including s.77

anchor.surface_text: On the footing that the mortgage is an anomalous mortgage... Section 98 says In the case of an anomalous mortgage, the rights and liabilities of the parties shall be determined by their contract... the question whether this section excludes the operation of other relevant provisions of the Act, including s.77

arguments.claim: Intention of parties determines lease vs mortgage: debt with land security for redemption makes mortgage whatever name called

anchor.surface_text: The only guiding rule that can be extracted from the cases on the subject is that the intention of the parties must be looked into and that once you get a debt with security of land for its redemption, then the arrangement is a mortgage by whatever name it is called  See Ghosh on Mortgages, V Edn., Vol. 1, p. 102 .

anchor.surface_text: Let us number examine the terms of the document Exhibit A  3  to ascertain the intention of the parties. ... In security of the payment of the peshgi money with or without interest mentioned in this ijara deed I, the executant, have mortgaged, hypothecated, encumbered and made liable the ijara property.

anchor.surface_text: But s. 77 enacts an exception to the mortgagees liability under cls.  g  and  h  of s. 76. Under that section  s. 77 , if there is a companytract between the mortgagor and the mortgagee... the mortgagee was expressly authorized to take the entire income from the land and appropriate the same towards interest

arguments.claim: Mention of interest rate does not prevent s.77; per Pandit Bachchu Lal v. Chaudhri Syed Mohammad Mahdi

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee, in Pandit Bachchu Lal v. Chaudhri Syed Mohammad Mah  1 , held that numberwithstanding the fact that a particular rate of interest was mentioned in the mortgage deed, there was a companytract within the meaning of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.text: We hold, agreeing with the High Court, that the document is a mortgage and not a lease.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, noscope for the argument in this case that the document is a lease and not a mortgage. We hold, agreeing with the High Court, that the document is a mortgage and not a lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention of parties gathered from document terms: existence of debt (peshgi Rs.31,701 with interest), land given as security, provision for repayment on expiry makes it mortgage regardless of nomenclature 'ijara' or 'lease'.

holdings.text: We hold that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies to the document and therefore the mortgagee is not liable to render any account to the mortgagor.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act applies to the document and therefore the mortgagee is not liable to render any account to the mortgagor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document contract authorizes mortgagee to appropriate entire receipts from property towards interest; fixed payment of Rs.435-4-0 to mortgagor is unconditional personal obligation not dependent on or deducted from receipts; mere mention of interest rate does not negate this.

holdings.text: Whether s. 77 applies or not, under the express terms of the contract, the appellant is not liable to render accounts for the excess receipts.

anchor.surface_text: Whether s. 77 applies or not, under the express terms of the contract, the appellant is not liable to render accounts for the excess receipts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming anomalous mortgage under s.98 TPA, contract terms (mortgagor agrees no claim on produce/income except fixed rent; mortgagee appropriates all towards interest) govern and exempt accounts liability, same result as s.77.

precedents.citation: Pandit Bachchu Lal v. Chaudhri Syed Mohammad Mah 1, 1933 37 C.W.N. 457

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee, in Pandit Bachchu Lal v. Chaudhri Syed Mohammad Mah 1 , held that notwithstanding the fact that a particular rate of interest was mentioned in the mortgage deed, there was a contract within the meaning of s. 77 of the Transfer of Property Act. It was a case of a mortgage with possession and a particular rate of interest was mentioned in the mortgage deed.
